name: clay roof tile production | clay roof tile | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28011/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of roof tile. Data was obtained from literature values (average data from 12 Swiss brick plants) that were corrected and updated for some flows. Note that no hard coal coke is used within these 12 plants.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of clay at the factory gate.

This dataset ends with the storage of the produced and packed roof tile at the factory. This datset includes the first ginding process, wet process (second ginding, mixing and plastifying), storage, forming (a compression molding method) and cutting, drying, firing, loading, packing and storage. The dataset doesn't include the charge of the wastewater and solid waste as no data was available. As roof tile are impermeables, no substances to make them porous are used in the process. Engobe is used to colour the tiles, however no information was obtained about the substance as it is confidential.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2392:Manufacture of clay building materials

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data was obtained from industries of Switzerland, Germany and Austria.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset corresponds to a mix of different brick production technologies (different firing fuels) in Austria, Germany and Switzerland.Share of heavy oil to natural gas about 20% to 80%;A difference to bricks is that roof tiles have to be more leek- and freeze-proven. Therefore pore forming media are not included in tile-production.;To have the roof tiles coloured often engobe  is used. The amount of one company in Switzerland is about 3.6g/kg burned tile. The composition of engobe is confidential and therefore it cannot be taken into account in this study. More than 50% of the waste water from cleaning of the engobe equipment is usually reused as mixing water for the wet process to plastify the clay. Solid waste is deposited in the mine and waste water is supplied purified to the municipal waste water treatment.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is extrapolated from "brick production" as it is basically the same production process. The heating fuel consumption and most emissions have been increased by the factor 1.5 (because of need to e.g. increase frost resistance compared to brick). The emissions HCl and HF have been increased by the factor 5. The electricity consumption has been approximately doubled.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data relates to 12 brick production plants in Germany, Austria and Switzerland; The estimation of infrastructure relates to one company in Switzerland (Ziegelei Gasser AG in Rapperswil BE),

exchanges.description: Roofing tiles are manufactured to produce their particular shape either with natural colour or with a slip coating (engobed) or a glazed finish. They are manufactured by extrusion or stamping. They usually have a porous, unsintered structure, and before being weatherproof they must be properly shaped, water impermeable, and able to bear sufficient load.

flow.name: clay roof tile
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2392:Manufacture of clay building materials

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based literature value. Data includes the total measured emissions within the system boundaries (mainly from combustion of the firing process).
A corresponding probing by an expert of the clay production industry has shown that the factor of 1.5 for CO2, CO, dust, NO2, SO2, and org. C is realistic (between 0.3 and 1.7). The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on literature value. Total measured emissions within the system boundaries. The share is based on EPA-Report: 25% of the total particulates.
A corresponding probing by an expert of the clay production industry has shown that the factor of 1.5 for CO2, CO, dust, NO2, SO2, and org. C is realistic (between 0.3 and 1.7). The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
EPA (1998) Brick and Structural Clay Product Manufacturing, Emissions Factor Documentation for AP-42, Final Report, Section 11.3. EPA Contract 68-D2-0159, Work Assignment No. I-0, MRI Project No. 4601-01. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards, Research Triangle Park/NC, Online-Version under: <http://www.epa.gov/ttn/chief/ap42/>.

Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based literature value. Data includes the total measured emissions within the system boundaries (mainly from combustion of the firing process).
The emission of hydrogen fluoride and hydrochloride acid is about 5 times higher than for the brick production. The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation, based on literature values. Light heating oil is used as combustible. It is assumed that the data is "net calorific value" with an efficiency of 0.85. 
The time for firing dried roof tiles is about 1.5 time longer than for bricks, according to (Weibel & Stritz (1995)). An expert of the clay production industry is very sceptical concerning this factor. He says that in nowadays tiles are burned in fast firing furnaces. As no better data are available nevertheless this factor has in general been used to increase the energy consumption and emission rates for brick production in order to adapt the values to tile production. 

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hellweg S., Hischier R., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2007) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent Data v2.0 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.

The time for firing dried roof tiles is about 1.5 time longer than for bricks, according to (Weibel & Stritz (1995)). An expert of the clay production industry is very sceptical concerning this factor. He says that in nowadays tiles are burned in fast firing furnaces. As no better data are available nevertheless this factor has in general been used to increase the energy consumption and emission rates for brick production in order to adapt the values to tile production. 

Further references:

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on personal communication from an expert of the clay production industry (Mr. H. Schmild). Electricity source considered from an electricity supply company. Uncertainty was adjusted as the information about electricity was rather low.

The electricity consumption for the production of 1kg roof tile in Europe is between 70 and 130Wh 5. For the dataset 80kW/kg is chosen. This assumption is rather optimistic. Anyway in relation to the consumption for brick it is about 5 to 10 times higher. This can be partly explained with the high-energy consumption for the flue gas cleaning plant as the cleaning time is about 1.5 times longer but no further explanation has been found.
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based literature value. Data includes the total measured emissions within the system boundaries.
A corresponding probing by an expert of the clay production industry has shown that the factor of 1.5 for CO2, CO, dust, NO2, SO2, and org. C is realistic (between 0.3 and 1.7). The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

flow.name: Benzene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based literature value. Data includes the total measured emissions within the system boundaries (mainly from combustion of the firing process).
A corresponding probing by an expert of the clay production industry has shown that the factor of 1.5 for CO2, CO, dust, NO2, SO2, and org. C is realistic (between 0.3 and 1.7). The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

flow.name: Sulfur dioxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on literature value. Total measured emissions within the system boundaries. It is assumed that the amount is 100% from combustion and therefore the share is calculated based on the emissions from the combustion. The share is based on EPA-Report: 75% of the total particulates.
A corresponding probing by an expert of the clay production industry has shown that the factor of 1.5 for CO2, CO, dust, NO2, SO2, and org. C is realistic (between 0.3 and 1.7). The source is based on the composition of the raw material clay which differs from the raw material which is used for brick.

Further references:
EPA (1998) Brick and Structural Clay Product Manufacturing, Emissions Factor Documentation for AP-42, Final Report, Section 11.3. EPA Contract 68-D2-0159, Work Assignment No. I-0, MRI Project No. 4601-01. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards, Research Triangle Park/NC, Online-Version under: <http://www.epa.gov/ttn/chief/ap42/>.

Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, < 2.5 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on literature values. Natural gas and propan are used as combustible. It is assumed that the data is "net calorific value" with an efficiency of 0.87.
The time for firing dried roof tiles is about 1.5 time longer than for bricks, according to (Weibel & Stritz (1995)). An expert of the clay production industry is very sceptical concerning this factor. He says that in nowadays tiles are burned in fast firing furnaces. As no better data are available nevertheless this factor has in general been used to increase the energy consumption and emission rates for brick production in order to adapt the values to tile production. 

Further references:
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hellweg S., Hischier R., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2007) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent Data v2.0 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.
